results.model_diagnosis: Doctor: Given the acute continuous spinning after a recent viral URI, horizontal unidirectional nystagmus suppressed by fixation, preserved hearing and a normal brain MRI, this presentation is most consistent with acute vestibular neuritis. DIAGNOSIS READY: Vestibular neuritis.

args.summary: Extracted three critical decision points where the team failed to integrate bilateral hearing loss into the final diagnosis, recommended targeted ENT/audiologic testing, focused history questions about timing and otologic symptoms, and early ENT consultation to distinguish labyrinthitis from vestibular neuritis.

result.result: {"status": "completed", "case_id": "MedQA_Ext_16", "summary": "Extracted three critical decision points where the team failed to integrate bilateral hearing loss into the final diagnosis, recommended targeted ENT/audiologic testing, focused history questions about timing and otologic symptoms, and early ENT consultation to distinguish labyrinthitis from vestibular neuritis.", "experience_file": "/Users/xiaofanlu/Documents/github_repos/uncertainty-aware-reasoning-agent/agent/memory/diagnostic_experiences.json"}

args.thought: Plan: Identify up to three critical decision points where diagnostic reasoning failed. For each, summarize situation (1-2 sentences), list 2-4 differential diagnoses at that time, propose a concrete action starting with ASK/PHYSICAL EXAM/REQUEST TEST/REQUEST IMAGE, and give 1-2 sentence rationale. Then save each learning experience via save_experience and finish with complete_analysis summarizing.

args.situation: 27-year-old male with acute onset constant spinning vertigo since this morning after a recent viral URI; reports bilateral decreased hearing on exam and audiometry, horizontal unidirectional nystagmus suppressed by fixation, normal MRI, vitals normal.
args.action: REQUEST TEST: Detailed audiogram with word recognition and bone conduction plus otoneurologic ENT exam (including tuning fork exam and otoscopy with pneumatic otoscopy) and ask: 'Did the hearing change begin exactly with the vertigo or did it progress after onset?'
args.rationale: Bilateral hearing loss documented on audiometry favors labyrinthine (peripheral) involvement rather than vestibular neuritis, and detailed audiometric and ENT exam findings (air-bone gaps, tympanic membrane/otoscopic signs) and precise timing of hearing change relative to vertigo would discriminate labyrinthitis from vestibular neuritis and guide management.

args.situation: After vestibular testing (Dix-Hallpike negative, head-impulse normal) and normal MRI, the doctor concluded vestibular neuritis despite reported bilateral decreased hearing on exam and audiometry and nystagmus reduced by fixation.
args.uncertainty: ["vestibular_neuritis", "labyrinthitis", "bilateral_otologic_process (otitis media, ototoxicity)", "central lesion not seen on MRI"]
args.action: ASK PATIENT: 'Have you had ear fullness, tinnitus, recent ear infections, or exposure to loud noise or ototoxic substances?'; REQUEST TEST: Repeat focused ENT exam and impulse testing with video head impulse (vHIT) and repeat audiometry including speech discrimination and bone conduction.
args.rationale: Explicitly eliciting otologic symptoms and using more sensitive vestibular tests (vHIT) and detailed audiometry helps confirm peripheral labyrinthine involvement; the combination of acute vertigo with new bilateral hearing loss strongly points to labyrinthitis rather than isolated vestibular neuritis.

args.situation: Initial assessment recognized viral prodrome and acute continuous vertigo with unidirectional horizontal nystagmus suppressed by fixation, but management concluded vestibular neuritis without integrating bilateral hearing loss finding.
args.action: REQUEST TEST: Tympanometry and full audiogram were done but interpretation was incomplete—REQUEST IMAGE: Otoscopic photography and REQUEST TEST: ENT consult for bedside diagnosis; ASK PATIENT: 'Was the hearing loss symmetric and constant since onset or fluctuating?','Do you have ear pain or discharge?'
args.rationale: When audiometry shows bilateral hearing loss, ensure ENT evaluation and integrate otologic exam findings; specialist input can confirm labyrinthitis and prevent mislabeling as isolated vestibular neuritis which would miss hearing involvement and alter treatment (e.g., possible steroids and antibiotics if infectious).

args.summary: Extracted three critical decision points where the team failed to integrate bilateral hearing loss into the final diagnosis, recommended targeted ENT/audiologic testing, focused history questions about timing and otologic symptoms, and early ENT consultation to distinguish labyrinthitis from vestibular neuritis.

results.model_diagnosis: I think this is an acute traumatic hemarthrosis of the right knee in a toddler rather than a hereditary bleeding disorder, given the isolated joint bleed, normal coagulation/platelet studies and genetic testing, and no prior bleeding history. DIAGNOSIS READY: Acute traumatic hemarthrosis of the right knee (hereditary hemophilia unlikely).

args.summary: Key teaching points: 1) Do not exclude hemophilia A based on a single normal one-stage FVIII assay or standard gene sequencing; use chromogenic assays and inversion/MLPA testing when clinical suspicion persists. 2) Thorough targeted family history and testing of affected relatives can reveal diagnoses missed in the proband. 3) Reconcile discordant lab results (prolonged ACT with normal panels) with repeat testing, mixing studies, and early orthopedic aspiration when hemarthrosis is present.

result.result: {"status": "completed", "case_id": "MedQA_Ext_15", "summary": "Key teaching points: 1) Do not exclude hemophilia A based on a single normal one-stage FVIII assay or standard gene sequencing; use chromogenic assays and inversion/MLPA testing when clinical suspicion persists. 2) Thorough targeted family history and testing of affected relatives can reveal diagnoses missed in the proband. 3) Reconcile discordant lab results (prolonged ACT with normal panels) with repeat testing, mixing studies, and early orthopedic aspiration when hemarthrosis is present.", "experience_file": "/Users/xiaofanlu/Documents/github_repos/uncertainty-aware-reasoning-agent/agent/memory/diagnostic_experiences.json"}

args.thought: We need to identify up to 3 critical decision points: (1) Overreliance on single normal FVIII level/genetic sequencing to exclude Hemophilia A — sequencing can miss large inversions/deletions and single assays can be falsely normal; (2) Failure to reconcile prolonged ACT and hemarthrosis — inconsistent labs should prompt repeat testing, mixing study, and specialized FVIII assays (chromogenic) and consider acute phase elevation of FVIII/vWF; (3) Under-appreciation of maternal family history — need targeted testing of uncle and maternal carrier analysis using tests that detect inversions/large rearrangements. For each, produce situation, uncertainty list, action (ASK or REQUEST TEST), and brief rationale.

args.situation: 18-month-old boy with acute right knee swelling; ultrasound shows hemarthrosis, no trauma reported, vitals stable, prolonged ACT on coag panel; initial Factor VIII level and F8 sequencing reported as normal, maternal F8 sequencing normal.
args.rationale: A single normal one-stage FVIII assay or gene sequencing can miss cases (e.g., inversion mutations, assay interference, or low-titer inhibitors); repeating with a chromogenic assay and performing a mixing study helps confirm true FVIII deficiency vs assay artifact or inhibitor and reconciles the clinical hemarthrosis with prolonged ACT.

args.situation: 18-month-old boy with spontaneous right knee hemarthrosis, family history of similar knee swelling in a maternal uncle but uncle's diagnosis unknown; many hemostasis tests (platelets, PT, aPTT, vWF, F8/F9 sequencing) reported normal.
args.action: ASK PATIENT: Obtain detailed family history—which maternal uncle, his clinical course, any documented lab results or bleeding episodes in maternal relatives; REQUEST TEST: Targeted testing of affected uncle (Factor VIII activity, genetic testing including inversion analysis) and MLPA/long-read sequencing for maternal F8 to detect large deletions/inversions.
args.rationale: Family history focused on the maternal male relative is crucial; also sequencing methods used may miss F8 inversion or large rearrangements—targeted testing of the affected uncle and maternal specialized genetic assays can reveal hemophilia A carriers or affected males missed by standard panels.

args.situation: 18-month-old boy with painful, non-weightbearing right leg, hemarthrosis confirmed on ultrasound, normal platelet count and inflammatory markers, but prolonged ACT and normal broad hemostasis panel results leading clinician to favor traumatic cause.
args.action: REQUEST TEST: Coagulation_retest_including_aPTT_with_different_reagents, Factor_VIII_inhibitor_assay_if_mixing_study_abnormal, and consider repeat imaging and orthopedic evaluation for aspiration and therapeutic joint drainage.
args.rationale: The presence of prolonged ACT with clinical hemarthrosis is discordant with a traumatic isolated bleed—retesting coagulation with varied reagents and doing mixing studies/inhibitor assays can uncover lab artifacts or inhibitors; early orthopedic aspiration can both confirm hemarthrosis and relieve pain while providing additional diagnostic fluid analysis.

args.summary: Key teaching points: 1) Do not exclude hemophilia A based on a single normal one-stage FVIII assay or standard gene sequencing; use chromogenic assays and inversion/MLPA testing when clinical suspicion persists. 2) Thorough targeted family history and testing of affected relatives can reveal diagnoses missed in the proband. 3) Reconcile discordant lab results (prolonged ACT with normal panels) with repeat testing, mixing studies, and early orthopedic aspiration when hemarthrosis is present.

results.model_diagnosis: Dr. Agent: DIAGNOSIS READY: Bilateral paraproteinemic retinopathy/central retinal vein occlusions secondary to a monoclonal gammopathy (most consistent with an IgM-related paraproteinemia causing retinal hemorrhages and progressive bilateral vision loss).

args.summary: Three key learning points saved: 1) When SPEP and downstream tests disagree, repeat and use more specific assays (reference immunofixation, free light chains, peripheral smear, cryocrit). 2) Evaluate and act on clinical hyperviscosity despite normal serum viscosity; obtain cryocrit and consider plasmapheresis when vision threatened. 3) For suspected Waldenstrom, pursue targeted marrow studies (flow cytometry, MYD88) as marrow involvement can be patchy and standard biopsy may be nondiagnostic.

result.result: {"status": "completed", "case_id": "MedQA_Ext_1", "summary": "Three key learning points saved: 1) When SPEP and downstream tests disagree, repeat and use more specific assays (reference immunofixation, free light chains, peripheral smear, cryocrit). 2) Evaluate and act on clinical hyperviscosity despite normal serum viscosity; obtain cryocrit and consider plasmapheresis when vision threatened. 3) For suspected Waldenstrom, pursue targeted marrow studies (flow cytometry, MYD88) as marrow involvement can be patchy and standard biopsy may be nondiagnostic.", "experience_file": "/Users/xiaofanlu/Documents/github_repos/uncertainty-aware-reasoning-agent/agent/memory/diagnostic_experiences.json"}

args.thought: Plan: Identify up to three critical decision points where the clinician's reasoning could be improved in this case of a 69-year-old woman with 3 weeks of headache and bilateral progressive vision loss and SPEP showing pentameric immunoglobulin. Likely learning points: (1) Reconciling discordant lab results (SPEP positive but immunofixation/IgM/viscosity normal) — need repeat/confirmatory tests (repeat SPEP with immunofixation at reference lab, serum free light chains, peripheral smear for rouleaux). (2) Management and assessment of suspected hyperviscosity/IgM-related retinal disease — don't rely solely on serum viscosity; evaluate clinical hyperviscosity signs, cryocrit, and consider urgent hematology/plasmapheresis if vision progressing. (3) Ensure disease-specific hematologic workup for Waldenstrom (flow cytometry and MYD88 mutation testing) rather than generic 'normal' hematology report or nondiagnostic bone marrow; request targeted marrow studies and repeat sampling if suspicion remains. Will save these as learning experiences with concise situation, uncertainty, action, and rationale.

args.situation: 69-year-old woman with 3 weeks of progressive bilateral blurry vision and headaches. Fundoscopy suggests retinal hemorrhages/retinal vein occlusions; SPEP shows increased pentameric immunoglobulin (suggesting IgM monoclonal gammopathy) but quantitative IgM, immunofixation, serum viscosity, and bone marrow biopsy were reported as normal.
args.uncertainty: ["IgM paraproteinemia/Waldenstrom_macroglobulinemia", "monoclonal gammopathy of undetermined significance (MGUS)", "other causes of retinal vein occlusion (hypertensive/atherosclerotic, hypercoagulable state)"]
args.action: REQUEST TEST: Repeat SPEP with immunofixation at a reference lab, serum free light chain assay, peripheral blood smear review for rouleaux/visible macroglobulins, and cryocrit measurement.
args.rationale: There is discordance between an abnormal SPEP and subsequent normal quantitative IgM/immunofixation and marrow results; repeat and more specific tests (reference immunofixation, free light chains, peripheral smear, cryocrit) help confirm or refute an IgM monoclonal process and detect paraprotein patterns missed by single assays.

args.situation: 69-year-old woman with progressive bilateral vision loss and fundoscopic findings suggestive of retinal vein occlusions/hemorrhages. SPEP indicates a pentameric immunoglobulin; serum viscosity and quantitative IgM were reported normal, and ophthalmology consult was unremarkable.
args.uncertainty: ["hyperviscosity_syndrome_due_to_IgM (Waldenstrom)", "paraproteinemic_retinopathy_without overt hyperviscosity", "non-paraprotein causes of retinal hemorrhage such as severe hypertensive retinopathy or CRVO from vascular risk factors"]
args.action: ASK PATIENT: Assess for clinical hyperviscosity symptoms (epistaxis, mucosal bleeding, headache, vertigo, tinnitus, transient visual disturbances) and perform targeted exam for mucosal/epistaxis and neurological deficits; REQUEST TEST: cryocrit, cryoglobulin fractionation, and consider urgent ophthalmology/heme joint evaluation for plasmapheresis if clinical hyperviscosity suspected despite normal serum viscosity.
args.rationale: Serum viscosity measurements can be normal early or be lab-dependent; urgent therapy (plasmapheresis) is indicated based on clinical hyperviscosity and strong suspicion of IgM-mediated disease affecting vision — waiting for normal quantitative labs risks irreversible vision loss.

args.situation: 69-year-old woman with monoclonal pentameric immunoglobulin on SPEP and progressive retinal findings; initial hematology consult and bone marrow biopsy were reported as normal but clinical suspicion for Waldenstrom remains.
args.uncertainty: ["Waldenstrom_macroglobulinemia (IgM lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma)", "MGUS with incidental paraprotein", "other lymphoproliferative disorder with low tumor burden"]
args.action: REQUEST TEST: Repeat bone marrow aspiration/biopsy with targeted studies including flow cytometry, immunohistochemistry for CD19/CD20/CD138, and molecular testing for MYD88 L265P mutation; REQUEST TEST: peripheral blood flow cytometry and repeat immunofixation at reference lab.
args.rationale: Waldenstrom can show patchy marrow involvement and low-level disease that may be missed; specialized immunophenotyping and MYD88 testing increase diagnostic yield and differentiate WM from MGUS and other B-cell disorders, guiding appropriate therapy.

args.summary: Three key learning points saved: 1) When SPEP and downstream tests disagree, repeat and use more specific assays (reference immunofixation, free light chains, peripheral smear, cryocrit). 2) Evaluate and act on clinical hyperviscosity despite normal serum viscosity; obtain cryocrit and consider plasmapheresis when vision threatened. 3) For suspected Waldenstrom, pursue targeted marrow studies (flow cytometry, MYD88) as marrow involvement can be patchy and standard biopsy may be nondiagnostic.

results.model_diagnosis: DIAGNOSIS READY: HPV‑negative keratinizing cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma of the penile shaft with a histologically identical lesion on the left middle finger (likely synchronous or cutaneous metastasis); recommend urgent wide local excision of both lesions and referral to urology/oncologic surgery for staging and management.

args.summary: Three key learning points: (1) Do not rely on superficial punch biopsies to distinguish in situ disease from invasive SCC—obtain excisional/deeper biopsy and explicit pathology comment about invasion. (2) Avoid premature full systemic staging and radical surgical recommendations until invasion is confirmed; tailor imaging and referral to histologic risk. (3) Interpret multiple similar cutaneous lesions cautiously—metastasis to distant skin is unlikely; consider synchronous multifocal Bowen's disease or autoinoculation and use clinical history, dermatopathology correlation, and targeted testing to guide management.

(2) Avoid premature full systemic staging and radical surgical recommendations until invasion is confirmed; tailor imaging and referral to histologic risk. (3) Interpret multiple similar cutaneous lesions cautiously\u2014metastasis to distant skin is unlikely; consider synchronous multifocal Bowen's disease or autoinoculation and use clinical history, dermatopathology correlation, and targeted testing to guide management.", "experience_file": "/Users/xiaofanlu/Documents/github_repos/uncertainty-aware-reasoning-agent/agent/memory/diagnostic_experiences.json"}

args.thought: We need to extract up to 3 critical decision points where diagnostic reasoning could be improved. Key issues: (1) Biopsy interpretation—punch biopsy showed epithelial atypia but report did not confirm dermal invasion; diagnosing invasive SCC vs Bowen's disease requires pathologist confirmation and possibly deeper/excisional biopsy. (2) Premature systemic staging (CT chest/abdomen/pelvis) and recommendation for urgent wide excision before confirming invasion—imaging and radical surgery usually reserved for confirmed invasive or high-risk lesions. (3) Interpreting the finger lesion as metastasis—metastasis between skin sites is unlikely; more likely synchronous primary or autoinoculation; management and counseling differ, and organ-sparing options exist. For each, craft situation, plausible differential at that point, a concrete action (ASK/PHYSICAL_EXAM/REQUEST_TEST), and concise rationale. Will save three experiences and then complete_analysis.

args.situation: 62-year-old male with painless, crusted erythematous plaques on the dorsal penile shaft and left middle finger; punch biopsies show marked epithelial atypia (nuclear hyperchromasia, multinucleation, increased mitoses) but no clear statement of dermal invasion. No systemic symptoms, HIV and syphilis negative, no lymphadenopathy on exam.
args.action: REQUEST TEST: Repeat or excisional biopsy (deeper/incisional or full-thickness excision) of penile lesion with clear request for assessment of invasion and margin status; request dermatopathology review with comment on depth of invasion and relation to adnexal structures.
args.rationale: Punch biopsies often sample only superficial epithelium and may not reliably detect invasive foci; confirming or excluding dermal invasion is the single most important distinction between Bowen's disease (in situ) and invasive SCC because it changes staging, urgency, and extent of surgery.

args.situation: After biopsy results showed epithelial atypia but no lymphadenopathy, the doctor ordered CT chest/abdomen/pelvis and recommended urgent wide local excision and oncology/urology referral assuming invasive penile SCC with potential spread.
args.action: REQUEST TEST: Hold systemic staging pending definitive histologic confirmation of invasion; REQUEST TEST: pelvic/inguinal ultrasound or targeted imaging only if clinical or histologic invasion is confirmed; PHYSICAL EXAM: repeat careful inguinal node exam and consider short-interval follow-up if in situ disease confirmed.
args.rationale: Full staging with CT is generally reserved for confirmed invasive or high-risk lesions; performing wide excision and systemic staging before confirming invasion risks overtreatment and unnecessary imaging—confirm invasion first to guide appropriate extent of surgery and need for oncologic referral.

args.situation: Two nearly identical lesions—penile plaque appeared first, then a similar lesion on the left middle finger two weeks later; pathology from both sites shows similar epithelial atypia.
args.action: ASK PATIENT: Detailed timeline of lesion onset, sexual practices, manual handling of genital lesions, and any rituals or treatments that could cause autoinoculation; REQUEST TEST: dermatopathology correlation to determine whether lesions share identical HPV or molecular markers, and consider testing for HPV subtypes and consulting dermatology for assessment of possible multifocal Bowen's disease.
args.rationale: Cutaneous metastasis from a penile primary to a finger is unlikely; synchronous primary in situ lesions or autoinoculation are more probable. Determining mechanism alters management (local therapy for multifocal in situ disease versus systemic therapy for metastatic disease) and avoids overstaging.

args.summary: Three key learning points: (1) Do not rely on superficial punch biopsies to distinguish in situ disease from invasive SCC—obtain excisional/deeper biopsy and explicit pathology comment about invasion. (2) Avoid premature full systemic staging and radical surgical recommendations until invasion is confirmed; tailor imaging and referral to histologic risk. (3) Interpret multiple similar cutaneous lesions cautiously—metastasis to distant skin is unlikely; consider synchronous multifocal Bowen's disease or autoinoculation and use clinical history, dermatopathology correlation, and targeted testing to guide management.
